header_summary:
Recent discussions within the Bitcoin development community have brought to light several key insights and proposals aimed at enhancing the network's functionality and security. Anthony Towns highlighted a noticeable shift in Bitcoin and Lightning Network transaction volumes, attributing a decline in on-chain transactions to increased Lightning Network adoption and Bitrefill's cessation of zero-confirmation transactions. This trend suggests a growing preference for faster, cheaper payment methods despite potential security concerns and the influence of business partnerships on network activity, raising questions about Bitcoin's decentralized ethos ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CABZBVTBupMcBbOUtLbMaEmAiWGsMwisNW+k+bTUJGsUad2=ZZg@mail.gmail.com/T/#m15d5410a336a81123ed162ab0e4a66566d0c12f8)).

Joshua Doman introduced "Graftleaf," a proposal enhancing Bitcoin's scripting capabilities through generalized program composition and coin delegation, marking a significant step forward in addressing the limitations of previous protocols. Graftleaf's innovative approach, emphasizing backward compatibility and improved privacy, underscores the community's ongoing efforts to refine and expand Bitcoin's functional landscape ([source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/0b5b560b-aa0c-4669-9621-67ccbecba516n@googlegroups.com/T/#u#m2f5da099a7ecd43f8a7495cba67f9a009ca57851)).

Meanwhile, Victor Kolobov's work on ColliderVM introduces a new blockchain protocol alternative aiming to streamline operations without fraud-proof windows, reflecting the community's pursuit of efficiency and reliability in blockchain technology. This, along with discussions on the optimal balance between privacy and usability in addressing unhardened paths and the exploration of innovative solutions to routing challenges within payment networks, illustrates the dynamic and collaborative nature of Bitcoin's development ecosystem. The community's dedication to addressing complex technical challenges is evident in their rigorous exploration of solutions like cooperative path queries and the evolution from OP_VAULT to OP_CHECKCONTRACTVERIFY (CCV), which promises to enhance Bitcoin's scripting language and security features significantly ([ColliderVM source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CAF0T6Xhf=Qb+B-3nBtR1Oiyk3gOO=o-8jdT0cJ6fRH=2azQvAg@mail.gmail.com/T/#u#mea3b6c36826b554b9c603514ebc0c95ef8f82585); [routing challenges source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/path-queries-overcoming-liquidity-uncertainty-and-other-routing-limitations/1672); [CCV source](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/withdrawing-op-vault-bip-345/1670)).

recent_posts.title: Re: [Opt-in full-RBF] Zero-conf apps in immediate danger
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin and Lightning Network's transaction volumes have significantly decreased recently.
- Bitrefill has stopped accepting zero-confirmation transactions, hinting at security concerns.
- Over half of Lightning Network's users come from business partnerships, impacting decentralization.

recent_posts.title: Graftleaf: Program Composition and Generic Delegation
recent_posts.summary:
- Joshua Doman introduces "Graftleaf" for program composition and coin delegation in Bitcoin.
- Graftleaf proposes a new Taproot leaf for executing multiple witness programs and enhancing security.
- The proposal offers backward compatibility, supports re-delegation, and improves privacy and fungibility.

recent_posts.title: ColliderVM protocol for computation and L2 bridges
recent_posts.summary:
- ColliderVM offers a novel blockchain protocol, eliminating fraud-proof needs.
- Further developments and a more refined protocol are expected from the team.
- Resources for understanding ColliderVM include a detailed paper, a video presentation, and an extensive discussion.

recent_posts.title: Avoiding xpub+derivation reuse across wallets, in a UX-friendly manner
recent_posts.summary:
- The proposal explores balancing usability and privacy by integrating randomness into export paths.
- Concerns include hardware signer compatibility and determining the proper randomness depth for privacy.
- The goal is to find a method that protects privacy without sacrificing user experience or compatibility.

recent_posts.title: Path Queries: Overcoming liquidity uncertainty and other routing limitations
recent_posts.summary:
- The discourse outlines challenges in payment network routing, highlighting liquidity and slow discovery issues.
- It proposes cooperative path queries to improve routing efficiency and reduce liquidity issues.
- The proposed solution aims to enhance network growth, decentralization, and address privacy concerns.

recent_posts.title: Withdrawing OP_VAULT (BIP-345)
recent_posts.summary:
- The evolution from OP_VAULT to OP_CHECKCONTRACTVERIFY marks significant progress in Bitcoin script security.
- CCV innovates with more efficient scripting, incorporating key VAULT features and setting benchmarks for future enhancements.
- Despite some limitations compared to VAULT, CCV's robust foundation is poised for future improvements in Bitcoin's security mechanisms.

active_posts.title: Relax OP_RETURN standardness restrictions
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core's standardness rules aim to mitigate DoS attacks, enable upgrades, and discourage data storage.
- The Citrea bridge utilizes Taproot outputs to embed data, circumventing OP_RETURN output limits.
- Proposals exist to remove OP_RETURN restrictions to prevent endorsing less desirable data storage practices.

active_posts.title: Unbreaking testnet4
active_posts.summary:
- Testnet4's difficulty reset rule, intended to ease development, has perpetuated significant issues.
- A proposed flag day hard fork on January 1, 2026, aims to remove this rule for improvement.
- The change seeks a balance between simulating Bitcoin's mainnet and facilitating developer testing.

active_posts.title: SwiftSync - smarter synchronization with hints
active_posts.summary:
- SwiftSync facilitates near-stateless, parallel Bitcoin blockchain validation using hints for unspent outputs.
- It improves validation efficiency by eschewing a constant UTXO set, aiming for a zero total hash aggregate.
- The protocol speeds up processing, especially on limited RAM devices, and seeks feedback on its comprehensive analysis.

active_posts.title: CTV+CSFS: Can we reach consensus on a first step towards covenants?
active_posts.summary:
- Covenants in Bitcoin protocol enhance transaction control and security through spend conditionality.
- They enable innovative financial instruments and complex smart contracts within the ecosystem.
- A dedicated wiki page provides comprehensive details on covenants' technical and application aspects.

active_posts.title: Op_inout_amount
active_posts.summary:
- The `OP_INOUT_AMOUNT` proposal aims to enhance Bitcoin Script with input and output stack functionality.
- It explores integrating with a 64bit op code and seeks community feedback on its design considerations.
- Modifications include new methods in `BaseTransactionSignatureChecker` to support these functionalities.

active_posts.title: SwiftSync -- Speeding up IBD with pre-generated hints (PoC)
active_posts.summary:
- The write-up analyzes `assumevalid` in SwiftSync, enhancing system efficiency by skipping some block verifications.
- It discusses safeguarding against inflation despite omitting certain validations, ensuring monetary policy integrity.
- SwiftSync's methods for parallel transaction order validation and innovative BIP30 check are explored for better scalability.

today_in_history_posts.title: Making OP_TRUE standard?
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Rusty discusses a fee prediction issue in the lightning protocol.
- He suggests using Eltoo and a 546 satoshi OP_TRUE for lower fees.
- Proposes P2SH as a solution to CPFP’s CSV output delays.

today_in_history_posts.title: New idea on decentralized identity and truth (Re: Numerifides)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The author introduces a Lightning-based decentralized identity system.
- Payments affect the visibility and prioritization of queries within the system.
- Future applications could include paid submissions for recommendations or advertisements.

today_in_history_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin scaling involves creating 50,000 off-chain "bitcoin banks" for weekly transactions.
- These banks balance security and affordability, while avoiding larger block sizes to prevent centralization.
- Innovations and protocols like OP_VAULT and Lightning Network aim to maintain Bitcoin's integrity and scalability.
